description.value: Safety Attributes need to be filled out
The requirement shall refine the Use Case it belongs to.

Summarize in this section the purpose of the (main) function described in this document in 2 to max. 5 sentences. Keep in mind that this chapter shall give only an overview about the function, details are specified in chapter 2, 3, and 4 in detailed requirements and should not be part of this section.

A function concept may has a certain variance, in particular if the variance can be perceived by the customer. E.g. a function may be designed for a local hosting, while there shall be a more advanced variant for the future, offering different or additional use cases. You can define the variants here and make sure each requirement is clearly assigned to one or more variants. If there is no variance for this function, delete this chapter.

attributes.title: Context & External Interfaces of the Function

description.value:
Description <Brief description which explains the whole picture.>
Precondition
  1. <required conditions which have to be fulfilled before the trigger can start the use case>
Trigger
  • <an event outside the system's scope which starts the use case>
Postcondition
  1. <state of the system after use case's execution>
Flow
  1. <step-by-step execution description - hook to identify system functions>

attributes.title: Explanation Use Cases of the Function

description.value: The Use Cases describe scenarios where the function gets an external request (e.g. by a user or another function) and responds to it. The Use Cases are structured by the lifecycle phases of the function. The Use Cases may be refined by requirements.

Complex Functions can be grouped to invariant subfunctions. This helps to reduce complexity and allow later a clear allocation to physical elements.
If you use subfunctions, the requirements of chapter 3 and 5 may be structured by sub-chapters.
In case of different variants of the system, the functional architecture may contain an overall set of functions for all variants. For each single instance a subset is chosen and allocated.
<Insert illustration of the functional diagrams as screenshot or copy>
Best practise: Filled by Systems architect, the model is prepared in a dedicated modelling tool, like EA, and a link is provided in this chapter. The preparation and definition of a functional architecture is further described in the Modelling Guide:

attributes.title: Context & External Interfaces of the Function

description.value:
Every functionality has its purpose: It provides and demands services to and from the outside world and interacts with its specific environment. Therefore, it is essential to assess the context carefully. This is the motivation to establish a context diagram. The functionality to be defined is represented as a black box and is the focus in this view. Furthermore, the context diagram shows system stakeholders, such as adjacent systems, user roles, processes, etc., who are interacting with the system.
The aim of this diagram is to reveal the specific system border. That means it separates the planned functionality from its environment. Furthermore a context diagram defines indirectly covered aspects, which aspects are part of the system context and to document the interfaces between them on a high level. Please note that the system border might change during the development, i.e. the according diagram has to be maintained constantly.
<Diagram of the Functionality's Context>
Best practise: to be worked out in a joined workshop including product management, systems engineering and architecting.
AgPL Attribut needs to be filled out
This chapter describes the risks of the HARA and the derived Safety Goals, Safe States and Functional Safety Requirements.

The functional safety concept describes the safety aspects of the function. It contains the safe state in case of a safety relevant event and all related requirements. The safety concept is based on functions a customer can experience, the hazard and risk analysis and the designated architecture. Derived from all inputs, the specification includes the functional safety requirements, with associated information, their allocation to architectural elements, and their behaviour necessary to achieve the safety goals.

This chapter lists the responsible person to manage this document and the authors providing content for this document.
Name Role
Max Mustermann Function Responsible
Mike Mechanic Assembly Group Responsible Intake
Heiner Hydraulic Assembly Group Responsible Hydraulic
Eve Electronics Assembly Group Responsible E/E

attributes.title: Purpose and content of the document

description.value:
This documents contains a conceptual description of a feature respectively function which can be experienced by the customer. This document contains an abstract description which can be reused across different products and product generations. The concept which is the scope of this document is not deployed to a specific technical system or component yet. This allows that technical concepts can be compared and justified properly (e.g. deployment to specific systems, assembly groups or modules). The functional concept shall contain technical details as less as possible since it shall be written in a solution-neutral way. Therefore, it closes the gap between the Product Requirement Specification including customer requirements and a concrete specification for certain components or even entire systems.
The document provides two perspectives at a functionality:
  • The static view includes a context analysis and (if required) a definition of sub-functions (Chapter )
  • the application view includes Use Case, which describes the behavior of the function (Chapter )
Please note that the content in this document is not created in a linear order, following chapter after chapter. Instead the document is structured in a way that it allows a reader to understand the specified function easily.

During development assumptions are necessary and often applied automatically to a project. Especially for concept descriptions a larger number of assumptions are common due to missing unambiguous customer specifications, missing knowledge about possible solutions, etc.
These assumption are usual and need to be documented in this chapter, e.g. that it is assumed that the combine harvesters are equipped with four wheels.
<List of assumptions>
Best practise: Filled by functional responsible

Standard text are written in black and you should leave them in the document for...

description.value: Standard text are written in black and you should leave them in the document for clarification purposes

attributes.title: How should the task be solved by the project?

description.value: How should the task be solved by the project?

attributes.title: Which objective should be achieved by system component?

description.value: Which objective should be achieved by system component?

attributes.title: A context model is useful for identifying the scope and all necessary interfaces...

description.value: A context model is useful for identifying the scope and all necessary interfaces of the system component (black box). The context should at least contain the elements of the preliminary product architecture. It is recommended to consider carefully external objects like users, other machines, special services or devices of the product’s surroundings during the component development.

attributes.title: Changes to development process defined in chapter 1.3 are documented in this cha...

description.value: Changes to development process defined in chapter 1.3 are documented in this chapter. Of course, each development process can and must be tailored for each specific project, e.g. the type of reviews depends on the safety context of the project.

attributes.title: The chapter system component overview provides a basic understanding of importan...

description.value: The chapter system component overview provides a basic understanding of important functions and use cases of the system component. The description should target non technicians and management. It is the first chapter which describes the target of development. This chapter should be used to introduce the system component to an external supplier.

attributes.title: Evolution and further development of the document
The requirements engineering and management tool is the Microsoft Team Foundatio...

description.value: The requirements engineering and management tool is the Microsoft Team Foundation Server (TFS). The architecture is specified with the help of Enterprise Architect (EA). The TFS is the leading tool. Graphical representations with the type requirement must be added to the TFS, e.g. a state machine modelled in EA. A graphical representation with state requirement must not be described in textual form additionally. All rules, regulations and attributes described in the RE Guide are valid for modelled requirements also.

attributes.title: Constraints are related to the given project context. They describe framework co...

description.value: Constraints are related to the given project context. They describe framework conditions for the technical realisation. Constraints for the project itself or stakeholders, e.g. time, schedule, budget, licensing, etc. should be documented in a project manual and not in the system component specification. Here mandatory technical solutions should be described.

attributes.title: After the first release of the document, changes to the document are of course p...

description.value: After the first release of the document, changes to the document are of course possible and common. However, the changes must be controlled by a change management process.

attributes.title: The release of the system component specification is based on the review process...

description.value: The release of the system component specification is based on the review process. The review is mandatory. The type of the review as well as the participants must be defined in each project. The content of the document regarding CPDP-TD milestones is described in the chapter 1.5. A release should contain requirements with status accdepted(Status will be defined in next release of TFS template: The status for released requirements should be “Accepted by project”) only. All other requirements are not reviewed and therefore not reliable.

attributes.title: The baselining and release management of the document should be described in the...

description.value: The baselining and release management of the document should be described in the configuration management plan (Please add link to document) for each project.

attributes.title: If this plan is not created, a baseline should be drawn before each review and f...

description.value: If this plan is not created, a baseline should be drawn before each review and for each release of the document at minimum. The name of the baseline should contain a mayor and a minor number as well as an abbreviation to mark release and intermediate baselines (e.g. REL_01_04 or INT_00_05).

attributes.title: For each requirement the regulations and definitions in the Requirements Enginee...

description.value: For each requirement the regulations and definitions in the Requirements Engineering Guide must be satisfied.

attributes.title: The minimum requirements to a system component specification are a description o...

description.value: The minimum requirements to a system component specification are a description of functional and quality requirements, the component architecture and a list of assumptions. Requirements must be broken down and uniquely mapped to the architectural elements.

attributes.title: For M2 system engineer and system architect must specify the architecture of the...

description.value: For M2 system engineer and system architect must specify the architecture of the system component. The system engineer should refine the functional requirements derived from the product (including quality requirements). The requirements must be reviewed by the corresponding domains and stakeholders.

attributes.title: The following rules should apply for the CLAAS CPDP-TD milestones:

description.value: The following rules should apply for the CLAAS CPDP-TD milestones:

attributes.title: The CLAAS internal CPDP-TD should be applied for the development of EE-systems a...

description.value: The CLAAS internal CPDP-TD should be applied for the development of EE-systems and CPDP-SW for components containing software only.

attributes.title: The system component specifications enables the specification and refinement of...

description.value: The system component specifications enables the specification and refinement of domain components based on the architecture. The document describes the framework conditions of the project as well as of the system component development. It must limit the number of possible technical solutions. Due to the black box view of the architectural elements, the system component specification shall not contain any technical details of the architectural elements itself.

attributes.title: If you want to exchange the document with external suppliers you should provide...

description.value: If you want to exchange the document with external suppliers you should provide necessary chapters only, e.g. you should exclude 1.3 – 1.5.

attributes.title: Purpose and content of the document
Furthermore, the document must contain a description of the architecture of the...

description.value: Furthermore, the document must contain a description of the architecture of the system component. Usually, the elements of the architecture are focused on hardware and mechanical design elements, e.g. µController, supply, sensors, actuators, etc. (Please note: functions which are realized in software are mapped to a µController.) This architecture is necessary to guideline the refinement of the functional requirements. The aim is to map the functional requirements unambiguously to the elements of the architecture. A further detailing of the functional requirements is not necessary. Each architectural element must be viewed as a black box.

attributes.title: The system component specification must ensure that all wishes and needs of at l...

description.value: The system component specification must ensure that all wishes and needs of at least one product specification are covered. Therefore the input documents for the system component specification is at least one product specifications as well as internal and external norms and standards. It is recommended to create a system context and a stakeholder analysis prior to the specification of the system component.

attributes.title: Target and boundaries of the document
Furthermore interfaces between the architectural elements must be specified.

description.value: Furthermore interfaces between the architectural elements must be specified.

attributes.title: Placeholder for your content are marked with brackets <…> or in grey colour, you...

description.value: Placeholder for your content are marked with brackets <…> or in grey colour, you should remove them and add your content

attributes.title: Each function is executed in at least on operating mode of the system component...

description.value: Each function is executed in at least on operating mode of the system component (see chapter 5.1). This chapter should list all modes in which the function is executed.

attributes.title: If the function is mapped to an architectural element this should be specified h...

description.value: If the function is mapped to an architectural element this should be specified here as requirement.

attributes.title: Please copy template #02 for each application and do not edit Template #01! It c...

description.value: Please copy template #02 for each application and do not edit Template #01! It could be removed at finalization of the specification. The name of the Functions must be unique within the system component specification. It should be composed of a noun and a verb. A function represents a set of functional and quality requirements which are group or categorized under the specific function. The template represents a superset and must be tailored for each function.

attributes.title: It could be necessary to configure the behaviour of a function. This may range f...

description.value: It could be necessary to configure the behaviour of a function. This may range from parameter for a filter function (filter time, type of filter) to country-specific differences of the behaviour. Parameters and configurations should be added as a list with a short description.

attributes.title: Focus of the section are the functions of the system component as well as the de...

description.value: Focus of the section are the functions of the system component as well as the decomposition of functional requirements, based on the system component architecture. The process is top-down. The product specification contains the description of the functions allocated to the system component. They must be refined by the system engineer and mapped to the elements of the architecture (hardware µController or mechanics). It must be ensured that the functional requirements on the lowest level are mapped to the elements unambiguously. The elements of the architecture are handled as a black-box. A further specification of the internal behaviour is not necessary.

attributes.title: A system component has different states of operation. Typical states are, clamp...

description.value: A system component has different states of operation. Typical states are, clamp states, power off, sleep mode, init/startup, normal run, restricted run or shutdown, to name some examples. These states are defined in this chapter. The operating modes and their interconnection should be illustrated with the help of a state machine. A description of the states and the transitions is necessary.

attributes.title: The system component architecture could be a sketch, a block diagram, or a SysML...

description.value: The system component architecture could be a sketch, a block diagram, or a SysML block and SysML internal block diagram. At this point no explicit definitions are given. The architect should use the explicit freedom to describe the architecture in a suitable way. The aim is to increase the understanding of developers or external suppliers.

attributes.title: The interface between the architectural elements shall be characterized by flow...

description.value: The interface between the architectural elements shall be characterized by flow of material, energy and information. The description should contain technical details (in contrast to the product specification). Each interface must have a unique name.

attributes.title: In the CLAAS context the system components is usually applied to different produ...

description.value: In the CLAAS context the system components is usually applied to different products/machines. Each of them represents a variant of the system component. The list of variants with a unique name should be added in the list below. If possible at this early stage a list of functionality or deviations from a standard list of functions should be added.

attributes.title: Example: self-diagnosis of the system: sensors and actuators, switches, open lin...

description.value: Example: self-diagnosis of the system: sensors and actuators, switches, open lines, short lines, RAM, ROM, EEPROM tests, in detail this must be covered in the functions, how is the test performed, error reaction

attributes.title: Example: norms and standards regarding environment, how should the system compon...

description.value: Example: norms and standards regarding environment, how should the system component be recycled

attributes.title: Example: availability of services or must the expected functionality work under...

description.value: Example: availability of services or must the expected functionality work under all conditions

attributes.title: Quality requirements define the framework conditions for the system component an...

description.value: Quality requirements define the framework conditions for the system component and therefore limit the scope of development. This chapter contains all quality requirements regarding the system component as well as regarding the architectural elements (if necessary). The following structure is a superset. It can be used as an example and must be adjusted for each project and possibly extended. In most cases quality requirements are specified in the chapter 5. If this is the case they should not be specified here again. The focus here are cross-cutting quality requirements which effect the whole system component.

If you don't want to use Diagrams for the specification of the behaviour, delete Chapter  and may  as necessary. Note that diagrams offer a much better overview about the structure and dependencies. They can also help to have more complete specifications.

attributes.title: Context & External Interfaces of the Function

description.value: A function concept may has a certain variance, in particular if the variance can be perceived by the customer. E.g. a function may be designed for a local hosting, while there shall be a more advanced variant for the future, offering different or additional use cases. You can define the variants here and make sure each requirement is clearly assigned to one or more variants. If there is no variance for this function, delete this chapter.

During development assumptions are necessary and often applied automatically to a project. Especially for concept descriptions a larger number of assumptions are common due to missing unambiguous customer specifications, missing knowledge about possible solutions, etc.
These assumption are usual and need to be documented in this chapter, e.g. that it is assumed that the combine harvesters are equipped with four wheels.
<List of assumptions>
Best practise: Filled by functional responsible
AgPL Attribut needs to be filled out

The functional safety concept describes the safety aspects of the function. It contains the safe state in case of a safety relevant event and all related requirements. The safety concept is based on functions a customer can experience, the hazard and risk analysis and the designated architecture. Derived from all inputs, the specification includes the functional safety requirements, with associated information, their allocation to architectural elements, and their behaviour necessary to achieve the safety goals.
This chapter describes the risks of the HARA and the derived Safety Goals, Safe States and Functional Safety Requirements.

Complex Functions can be grouped to invariant subfunctions. This helps to reduce complexity and allow later a clear allocation to physical elements.
If you use subfunctions, the requirements of chapter 3 and 5 may be structured by sub-chapters.
In case of different variants of the system, the functional architecture may contain an overall set of functions for all variants. For each single instance a subset is chosen and allocated.
<Insert illustration of the functional diagrams as screenshot or copy>
Best practise: Filled by Systems architect, the model is prepared in a dedicated modelling tool, like EA, and a link is provided in this chapter. The preparation and definition of a functional architecture is further described in the Modelling Guide:

attributes.title: Context & External Interfaces of the Function

description.value:
Every functionality has its purpose: It provides and demands services to and from the outside world and interacts with its specific environment. Therefore, it is essential to assess the context carefully. This is the motivation to establish a context diagram. The functionality to be defined is represented as a black box and is the focus in this view. Furthermore, the context diagram shows system stakeholders, such as adjacent systems, user roles, processes, etc., who are interacting with the system.
The aim of this diagram is to reveal the specific system border. That means it separates the planned functionality from its environment. Furthermore a context diagram defines indirectly covered aspects, which aspects are part of the system context and to document the interfaces between them on a high level. Please note that the system border might change during the development, i.e. the according diagram has to be maintained constantly.
<Diagram of the Functionality's Context>
Best practise: to be worked out in a joined workshop including product management, systems engineering and architecting.

  2. Update Work Item title
  3. Select review type by entering the correct type below. Delete "Functional-safety relevant" if no functional safety relevant requirements are included in the review.
  4. Document the participants incl. their roles
  5. Document the objects of review. Best Practice: Copy&Paste the Requirements as described here 
  6. Document the findings
  7. Document derived tasks and link them  (e.g. Azure DevOps Work Item)

attributes.title: Purpose and content of the document

description.value:
This documents contains a conceptual description of a feature respectively function which can be experienced by the customer. This document contains an abstract description which can be reused across different products and product generations. The concept which is the scope of this document is not deployed to a specific technical system or component yet. This allows that technical concepts can be compared and justified properly (e.g. deployment to specific systems, assembly groups or modules). The functional concept shall contain technical details as less as possible since it shall be written in a solution-neutral way. Therefore, it closes the gap between the Product Requirement Specification including customer requirements and a concrete specification for certain components or even entire systems.
The document provides two perspectives at a functionality:
  • The static view includes a context analysis and (if required) a definition of sub-functions (Chapter )
  • the application view includes Use Case, which describes the behavior of the function (Chapter )
Please note that the content in this document is not created in a linear order, following chapter after chapter. Instead the document is structured in a way that it allows a reader to understand the specified function easily.

Description <Brief description which explains the whole picture.>
Precondition
  1. <required conditions which have to be fulfilled before the trigger can start the use case>
Trigger
  • <an event outside the system's scope which starts the use case>
Postcondition
  1. <state of the system after use case's execution>
Flow
  1. <step-by-step execution description - hook to identify system functions>
Safety Attributes need to be filled out

attributes.title: Explanation Use Cases of the Function

description.value: The Use Cases describe scenarios where the function gets an external request (e.g. by a user or another function) and responds to it. The Use Cases are structured by the lifecycle phases of the function. The Use Cases may be refined by requirements.

Summarize in this section the purpose of the (main) function described in this document in 2 to max. 5 sentences. Keep in mind that this chapter shall give only an overview about the function, details are specified in chapter 2, 3, and 4 in detailed requirements and should not be part of this section.
